body:
Comment 1: 
the x in J is one level deeper than x in I, so those two x's are
not colliding.

http://golang.org/ref/spec#Selector:
A selector f may denote a field or method f of a type T, or it may refer to a field or
method f of a nested anonymous field of T. The number of anonymous fields traversed to
reach f is called its depth in T. The depth of a field or method f declared in T is
zero. The depth of a field or method f declared in an anonymous field A in T is the
depth of f in A plus one.
...
For a value x of type T or *T where T is not an interface type, x.f denotes the field or
method at the shallowest depth in T where there is such an f. If there is not exactly
one f with shallowest depth, the selector expression is illegal.
_Status changed to **WorkingAsIntended**._
